description: This course relies on a variety of sociological perspectives to examine the role of the media and popular culture in society, with a particular emphasis on the power of the entertainment industries, the relationship between cultural consumption and status, and the social organization of leisure activities from sports to shopping. Specific course topics include the globalization of branding and popular culture, the rise of aesthetics and style in everyday life, the importance of social networks in the diffusion of fads, fashions, and mass media; and the social effects of new media technologies in the digital age.
name: SOC. OF MEDIA & POP CULT

values.comments:
This class examines the role of media and popular culture in society.  This class focuses on the power of the entertainment industries as well as the relationship between cultural consumption and one’s status. This class also investigates the globalization of brands as well as the roles of social networks in starting trends and fads.
The majority of students in this class felt that the course material was very “interesting” and “stimulating.” However, some students felt that “they really learned nothing new from this class.”
Overall, the students enjoyed Professor Grazian’s knowledge of the material and how he was able to “take somewhat abstract concepts and apply them to pop culture.”  However, students were disappointed in that “the many essays were all graded very differently by each TA.”  Many also felt that “the course expectations were not exactly made clear.”
This class had both underclassman and upperclassman.  Quite a few took it to fulfill either a sector or major requirement.
